Functional defect: STING activates both the NF-κB and IRF3 transcription pathways to induce the expression of IFN
Associated features: Skin vasculopathy, inflammatory lung disease, systemic autoinflammation and ICC, FCL

Functional defect: STING activates both the NF-κB and IRF3 transcription pathways to induce the expression of IFN
Associated features: FTT, early-onset rash, fever, dyspnea, interstitial lung disease/pneumonitis, polyarthritis, autoAbs, increased inflammatory markers, IFN gene signature. Phenocopy of SAVI due to AD GOF TMEM173

Functional defect: ADAs deactivate extracellular adenosine and terminate signaling through adenosine receptors
Associated features: Polyarteritis nodosa, childhood-onset, early-onset recurrent ischemic stroke and fever; some patients develop hypogammaglobulinemia

Functional defect: Intracellular accumulation of abnormal ssDNA species leading to increased type I IFN production
Associated features: Classical AGS, SLE, FCL

Functional defect: Intracellular accumulation of abnormal ssDNA species leading to increased type I IFN production
Associated features: Classical AGS, SLE, FCL

Functional defect: Intracellular accumulation of abnormal RNA-DNA hybrid species leading to increased type I IFN production
Associated features: Classical AGS, SP

Functional defect: Intracellular accumulation of abnormal RNA-DNA hybrid species leading to increased type I IFN production
Associated features: Classical AGS

Functional defect: Intracellular accumulation of abnormal RNA-DNA hybrid species leading to increased type I IFN production
Associated features: Classical AGS

Functional defect: Controls dNTPs in the cytosol, failure of which leads to increased type I IFN production
Associated features: Classical AGS, FCL

Functional defect: Catalyzes the deamination of adenosine to inosine in dsRNA substrates, failure of which leads to increased type I IFN production
Associated features: Classical AGS, BSN, SP

Functional defect: Catalyzes the deamination of adenosine to inosine in dsRNA substrates, failure of which leads to increased type I IFN production
Associated features: Classical AGS, BSN, SP

Functional defect: IFIH1 gene encodes a cytoplasmic viral RNA receptor that activates type I interferon signaling through the MAVS adaptor molecule
Associated features: Classical AGS, SLE, SP, SMS

Functional defect: DNase II degrades and eliminates DNA. Loss of DNase II activity induces type I interferon signaling
Associated features: AGS

Functional defect: Increased IFN signaling in fibroblasts
Associated features: AGS, type 1 IFN-opathy

Functional defect: Increased IFN signaling in fibroblasts
Associated features: AGS, type 1 IFN-opathy

Functional defect: Increased type I IFN signaling in cell lines and patient cells
Associated features: AGS, type 1 IFN-opathy

Disease: Pediatric SLE due to DNASE1L3 deficiency
Functional defect: DNASE1L3 is an endonuclease that degrades extracellular DNA. DNASE1L3 deficiency decreases clearance of apoptotic cells
Associated features: Very early-onset SLE, reduced complement levels, autoantibodies (dsDNA, ANCA), lupus nephritis, hypocomplementemic urticarial vasculitis syndrome

Functional defect: Upregulation of IFN through mechanism possibly relating to pDCS
Associated features: Short stature, SP, ICC, SLE, thrombocytopenia and autoimmune hemolytic anemia, possibly recurrent bacterial and viral infections

Functional defect: Defective negative regulation of ISG15 leading to increased IFN
Associated features: TORCH-like syndrome, autoinflammation, and mycobacterial disease

Functional defect: Increased interferon from recognition of RNA
Associated features: Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis, skin rash

Functional defect: ↑serum levels of IL-1, IL-18, IFN-α↑, ferritin, sCD25, CRP, etc. Mutation affects actin function, ↓ NK cell cytotoxicity
Associated features: Neonatal onset: pancytopenia, fever, rash, hepatosplenomegaly, multisystemic inflammation, myelofibrosis/proliferation, HLH, enterocolitis; recurrent GIT/URT infections; neurodevelopmental delay, FTT

Functional defect: Patient cells hypersensitive to IFN-α, GOF for induction of the late (not early) response to type 1 IFNs due to impaired interaction of mutant STAT2 with USP18, a negative regulator of type 1 IFN responses
Associated features: Severe fatal early-onset autoinflammation, ↑serum IFN-α, IL-6, TNF-α, phenocopy of USP18 deficiency

Functional defect: Elevated ISG expression, increased serum type 1 IFNs
Associated features: Predominantly neurological defects (development delay, spasticity)
Chronic mucocutaneous ulceration; Impaired NF-κB activation; reduced production of inflammatory cytokines

Functional defect: Leukocyte TLR7-dependent type I/III IFN production
Associated features: Patients with RELA DN mutations shared clinical phenotypes with RELA haploinsufficiency, presenting chronic mucocutaneous ulcerations and autoimmune hematological disorders such as immune thrombocytopenia (ITP) and neutropenia. However, patients with RELA DN mutations additionally presented periodic fever, IBD juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), and skin involvement

Functional defect: Increased pyrin inflammasome-mediated induction of IL-1β
Associated features: Recurrent fever, serositis, and inflammation responsive to colchicine. Predisposes to vasculitis and inflammatory bowel disease, SAA amyloidosis

Functional defect: Usually, M694del variant. Other missense variants in the B-Box and CC domains cause constitutive pyrin activation
Associated features: Recurrent fever, serositis, and inflammation responsive to colchicine. Predisposes to vasculitis and inflammatory bowel disease, SAA amyloidosis

Disease: Pyogenic sterile arthritis, pyoderma gangrenosum, acne (PAPA) syndrome, hyperzincemia, and hypercalprotectinemia
Functional defect: Activation of the pyrin inflammasome; high production of IL-1 and IL-18 cytokines; interferon signature
Associated features: Destructive arthritis, inflammatory skin rash, myositis

Functional defect: Defect in production of isoprenoids, which are synthesized via mevalonate pathway and play a role in regulation of many signaling pathways
Associated features: Periodic fever and leukocytosis with usually high IgD levels

Functional defect: Similar to MVK deficiency, increased IL-1β
Associated features: Recurrent fever episodes, arthritis, and cytopenia

Functional defect: Activation of cryopyrin inflammasome results in increased production of IL-1/IL-18 cytokines and cell death via pyroptosis
Associated features: Urticaria, SNHL, SAA amyloidosis

Functional defect: Activation of cryopyrin inflammasome results in increased production of IL-1/IL-18 cytokines and cell death via pyroptosis
Associated features: Nonpruritic urticaria, arthritis, chills, fever, and leukocytosis after cold exposure

Disease: Neonatal-onset multisystem inflammatory disease (NOMID)/chronic infantile neurological cutaneous and articular syndrome (CINCA)
Functional defect: Activation of cryopyrin inflammasome results in increased production of IL-1/IL-18 cytokines and cell death via pyroptosis
Associated features: Neonatal-onset rash, chronic meningitis, and arthropathy with fever and inflammation

Disease: Keratitis fugax hereditaria associated with c.61G>C; NLRP3
Functional defect: Activation of cryopyrin inflammasome results in increased production of IL-1/IL-18 cytokines and cell death via pyroptosis
Associated features: Episodic conjunctival injection, ocular pain, photophobia, foreign body sensation, and excessive tearing during acute attacks. Corneal opacities during attacks

Functional defect: Activation of cryopyrin inflammasome results in increased production of IL-1/IL-18 cytokines and cell death via pyroptosis
Associated features: Nonpruritic urticaria, arthritis, chills, fever, and leukocytosis after cold exposure

Affected cells: PMNs, monocytes, macrophages, intestinal epithelial cells
Functional defect: GOF mutation in NLRC4 results in elevated secretion of IL-1β and IL-18, as well as macrophage activation
Associated features: Severe enterocolitis and macrophage activation syndrome

Affected cells: PMNs, monocytes, macrophages, intestinal epithelial cells
Functional defect: GOF mutation in NLRC4 results in elevated secretion of IL-1β and IL-18, as well as macrophage activation
Associated features: Severe enterocolitis and macrophage activation syndrome

Disease: APLAID or autoinflammation, antibody deficiency, and immune dysregulation
Functional defect: Mutations affect the autoinhibitory domains and activate NF-κB and MAPK pathways
Associated features: Cold urticaria hypogammaglobulinemia, impaired humoral immunity, autoantibodies, autoinflammation, granulomas

Disease: PLAID or familial cold autoinflammatory syndrome 3
Functional defect: Mutations affect the autoinhibitory domains and activate NF-κB and MAPK pathways
Associated features: Cold urticaria hypogammaglobulinemia, impaired humoral immunity, autoantibodies, autoinflammation, granulomas

Disease: Autoinflammation with arthritis and dyskeratosis (AIADK; NLRP1 deficiency)
Functional defect: Systemic elevation of IL-18, IL-1β, caspase 1, suggesting activation of NLRP1 inflammasome
Associated features: Dyskeratosis, autoimmunity, and arthritis

Functional defect: Spontaneous production of IL-1β and IL-18 cytokines in keratinocytes
Associated features: Palmoplantar carcinoma, corneal scarring; recurrent respiratory papillomatosis

Disease: Autoinflammation with episodic fever and lymphadenopathy/cleavage-resistant RIPK1-induced autoinflammatory syndrome/CRIA
Functional defect: TNF-induced cell death via apoptosis and necroptosis
Associated features: Long-lasting fever episodes, lymphadenopathy, splenohepatomegaly, ulcers, arthralgia, GI features

Disease: Chronic recurrent multifocal osteomyelitis and congenital dyserythropoietic anemia (Majeed syndrome)
Functional defect: Dysregulation in cholesterol synthesis impairs the negative regulation of NLRP3 in macrophages resulting in high production of IL-1
Associated features: Chronic recurrent multifocal osteomyelitis, transfusion-dependent anemia, cutaneous inflammatory disorders

Functional defect: Mutations in the extracellular domain of 55-kD TNF receptor cause protein misfolding and intracellular receptor retention resulting in upregulation of ER stress
Associated features: Recurrent fever, serositis, rash, and ocular or joint inflammation

Functional defect: Mutations in nucleotide binding site of CARD15 result in constitutive activation of NOD2 noadosome nd upregulation of NF-κB signaling
Associated features: Uveitis, granulomatous synovitis, camptodactyly, rash, and cranial neuropathies; 30% develop Crohn’s colitis

Functional defect: Defective TNF-α production
Associated features: Early-onset diarrhea and skin lesions

Disease: DIRA (deficiency of the interleukin-1 receptor antagonist)
Functional defect: Mutations in the IL-1 receptor antagonist allow unopposed action of IL-1α and IL-1β
Associated features: Neonatal onset of sterile multifocal osteomyelitis, periostitis, and pustulosis

Disease: Loss of IL-1R1 sensitivity to IL-Ra (LIRSA/CRMO3) (1 patient)
Functional defect: Activated myeloid cells. Loss of IL-1R1 biding to endogenous IL-Ra
Associated features: Arthritis, osteolytic/sclerotic bone lesions, poor growth, no rash, no fever

Functional defect: Mutations in the IL-36 receptor antagonist allow unopposed action of IL-1α and IL-1β
Associated features: Pustular psoriasis

Functional defect: Defect in nucleoside transport functions of hENT3 leads to histiocytic infiltration of numerous organs
Associated features: Hyperpigmentation hypertrichosis, hepatosplenomegaly, heart anomalies, hearing loss, hypogonadism, low height, and occasionally hyperglycemia/diabetes mellitus

Functional defect: Mutations in CARD14 activate the NF-κB pathway and production of IL-8
Associated features: Psoriasis

Functional defect: Hyperactivated macrophages and osteoclasts, increased NF-κB signaling
Associated features: Bone degeneration in jaws

Disease: PRAAS-CANDLE (chronic atypical neutrophilic dermatitis with lipodystrophy)
Functional defect: Proteasome dysfunction with accumulation of ubiquitinated proteins and ER stress. Increased interferon signature
Associated features: Contractures, panniculitis, ICC, fevers

Disease: PRAAS-CANDLE (chronic atypical neutrophilic dermatitis with lipodystrophy)
Functional defect: Proteasome dysfunction with accumulation of ubiquitinated proteins and ER stress. Increased interferon signature
Associated features: Panniculitis, lipodystrophy, autoimmune hemolytic anemia

Disease: PRAAS-CANDLE (chronic atypical neutrophilic dermatitis with lipodystrophy)
Functional defect: Proteasome dysfunction with accumulation of ubiquitinated proteins and ER stress. Increased interferon signature
Associated features: Periorbital and hand–foot annular rash (neutrophilic dermatosis), microcytic anemia, long slender fingers, hepatomegaly and splenomegaly

Disease: PRAAS-CANDLE (chronic atypical neutrophilic dermatitis with lipodystrophy)
Functional defect: Proteasome dysfunction with accumulation of ubiquitinated proteins and ER stress. Increased interferon signature

Disease: PRAAS-CANDLE (chronic atypical neutrophilic dermatitis with lipodystrophy)
Functional defect: Proteasome dysfunction with accumulation of ubiquitinated proteins and ER stress. Increased interferon signature
Associated features: Panniculitis, lipodystrophy, autoimmune hemolytic anemia

Functional defect: Increased accumulation of ubiquitinated proteins and ER stress with increased IFN signaling mediated by increased PKR signaling
Associated features: CANDLE (chronic atypical neutrophilic dermatitis with lipodystrophy)/ interstitial lung disease in one patient, liver disease in one patient. Recurrent and opportunistic infections. Low CD8 T cells, skewing toward naïve T cells. Low B cells and positive autoantibodies

Functional defect: Decreased protein expression and reduced proteasome activities. Elevated levels of inflammatory cytokines (IL-6, IL-18, IP-10, IFN-α), liver enzymes in blood and CSF (IFN-α), hyperactivation of IFN-α, pSTAT1
Associated features: Severe autoinflammatory phenotype (neonatal-onset fever, skin rash, myositis, severe pulmonary hypertension, basal ganglia calcification), periodic inflammatory exacerbation; immunodeficiency. Partial phenocopy of PRAAS

Functional defect: ↑ peripheral blood type I IFN gene signature has been reported for some patients
Associated features: Intellectual disability, developmental delay, urticarial skin rash, elevated interferon signature

Functional defect: Defective intracellular transport via the coat protein complex I (COPI). Exacerbated STING-mediated type I interferon response
Associated features: Autoimmune inflammatory arthritis and interstitial lung disease with Th17 dysregulation and autoantibody production

Functional defect: Increase LUBAC induction of NF-κB and interferon activation leading to high proinflammatory cytokine levels. Increase in TNF-induced cell death
Associated features: Fever, diarrhea, skin abscesses, panniculitis

Disease: Dominant negative OTULIN-related autoinflammatory syndrome (3 patients)
Functional defect: Decreased catalytic activity, accumulation of linear ubiquitin chains, increased TNF-induced cell death,
Associated features: Spontaneous systemic inflammation

Functional defect: Increased activity of caveolin-1 stabilizes ADAM10 receptor for S. aureus toxin
Associated features: Susceptibility to S. aureus infections in epithelial cells

Functional defect: Defective inhibition of NF-κB signaling pathway
Associated features: Arthralgia, mucosal ulcers, ocular inflammation

Functional defect: Disrupted TLR3 translocation
Associated features: Pustular psoriasis

Functional defect: Deficient inhibition of LPS in intestine
Associated features: Inflammatory bowel disease

Functional defect: Granulomatous colitis
Associated features: Inflammatory bowel disease

Functional defect: Increased inflammasome activity due to defective checkpoint signaling
Associated features: Panniculitis, HLH, polyclonal cutaneous T-cell infiltrates or T-cell lymphoma

Affected cells: Outer mitochondrial membrane of all cells
Functional defect: C2orf69 regulates mitochondrial function; protein deficiency causes respiratory chain defects
Associated features: Early-onset severe autoinflammation disorder, often fatal. Global developmental delay, with recurrent seizures, muscle weakness due to glycogen deposits

Functional defect: Increased SYK phosphorylation, enhanced NF-κB, JNK, and ERK signaling. Mutated T cells are hypersensitive to stimulation and produce various proinflammatory chemokines and cytokines (IL-17, IL-22, TNF, IFN-γ)
Associated features: Recurrent infections, multi-organ inflammation/inflammatory disease (gut, skin, CNS, lung, liver), B-cell lymphoma reported in 2 pts

Functional defect: Increased kinase activity of HCK mutant in vitro; ↑ production of inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, IL-6, IL-8, TNF-α), ROS
Associated features: Cutaneous vasculitis, inflammatory leukocyte infiltration of the lungs (pulmonary fibrosis) and skin, anemia, hepatosplenomegaly

Functional defect: Mutant NEMO lacks exon 5 (NEMO-Dex5), fails to bind TBK1; NEMO-Dex5 stabilized IKKi, strong NF-κB, and interferon gene expression signatures
Associated features: Fever, skin rash, systemic autoinflammation, infections, CNS involvement, panniculitis, uveitis, hepatosplenomegaly, ectodermal dysplasia

Functional defect: Autoinflammation driven by TNF-induced RIPK1-dependent cell death
Associated features: Chronic systemic autoinflammation (polyarthritis, vasculitis, rash); delayed neurocognitive development

Disease: Retinal dystrophy, optic nerve edema, splenomegaly, anhidrosis, and headache (ROSAH)
Functional defect: Immune activation with increased NF-κB signaling, STAT1 phosphorylation, and interferon gene expression signature
Associated features: Retinal dystrophy, optic nerve edema, splenomegaly, anhidrosis, and migraine headache, fever, arthritis, colitis, dental abnormalities

Disease: LYN GOF; Systemic autoinflammatory disease with vasculitis, SAIDV
Functional defect: Activated endothelial cells, constitutively active neutrophils
Associated features: Diffuse purpuric rash/atopic dermatitis, fever, hepatosplenomegaly, liver fibrosis/calcifications, arthritis, periorbital edema, respiratory insufficiency, colitis, poor growth

Affected cells: Impaired development of germinal centers in secondary lymphoid organs, low CD20+cells, increased memory B cells
Functional defect: Defect in LUBAC function, attenuated canonical NF-κB responses, increased TNF-induced cell death
Associated features: Arthritis, fever, colitis, amylopectinosis

Functional defect: Unstimulated fibroblasts produce high levels of IL-6
Associated features: Skin sclerosis, poor wound healing, joint contractures, mucosal ulcerations
